CEDAR SHAKES
main
exterior
interior
Navigation options:
VENTILATION
Cedar Shingles are both beautiful and
durable, rustic type roof & wall coverings.
The beauty and historic value is unmatched.
Modern building codes vary in each state and
add strength to the home in general, but can
also drastically reduce the life of the shingle
on a roof. Attic ventilation is critical to the
life of this product. Do not store boxes or other items that will restrict air flow in these areas. On historic homes without sheathing, there was ample ventilation. Any extra measures (such as gable vents) should be considered to extend the roof life.
Mold, mildew and fungus are the basic
culprits of deterioration.

Mildew can usually be treated easily with a mixture of bleach and water (50/50) and then scrubbed with a brush. After application be sure to thoroughly rinse the shingles with clean water.
Moss can usually be treated the same way, except for excessive growth that may require a special herbicide that contains zinc sulfate. Usually 2 applications are needed using the same method as described above for mildew. Be sure to always read directions on any chemical products used for safety.

Keep trees with overhanging branches trimmed back to prevent moss from spreading. More sunlight will naturally kill new growth.
See also: Roofing
Oregon State University Extension Association (OSUEA)

cedar installations as prepared by Oregon State University
